close_symbols: types of Data.Cb.Ptr.VaHook / Data.Cb.Ptr.VaHandler / Data.Cb.Ptr.SimpleHook / Data.Cb.Ptr.SimpleHandler (callback function-pointer prototypes)
explanation:
Why each symbol is required to check the MISRA rule (a function parameter shall not be modified):

- va_list (type), va_copy, va_end: The function uses va_list ArgList and calls va_copy(ArgListCopy, ArgList) and later passes ArgList to handler functions. Whether or not these operations modify the ArgList parameter (or require special handling because va_list is an array/type that decays) depends on the exact definition/semantics of va_list and the va_copy/va_end implementation on the target platform. We need the definitions to determine if the code performs an impermissible modification of the parameter ArgList.

- UT_StubTableEntry_t (full struct definition): The code dereferences StubPtr and accesses StubPtr->Data.Cb and other fields. The layout shows what the callback fields are (and their types). The full struct is needed to locate the callback pointer fields and confirm whether any of the struct accesses could alias or write through a function parameter (e.g., if any parameter were a pointer into this struct). It also shows whether any fields are pointers that could affect whether passing parameters to functions results in modifications of the original parameter objects.

- types of Data.Cb.Ptr.VaHook / Data.Cb.Ptr.VaHandler / Data.Cb.Ptr.SimpleHook / Data.Cb.Ptr.SimpleHandler (callback prototypes): The code calls these callbacks with ArgList or ArgListCopy. To know if passing ArgList to them constitutes modifying the function parameter (per MISRA) we must know whether those prototypes accept va_list by value or by pointer/reference (e.g., va_list*). If a callback takes a va_list* or non-const pointer to the caller's parameter storage, that could mean the parameter is being modified; if they take va_list by value, the call does not modify the parameter variable in this function. The exact prototypes are therefore essential.

- UT_EntryKey_t (typedef): FuncKey is passed to UT_GetStubEntry and UT_Stub_FindRetvalConfig; we must know whether UT_EntryKey_t is an integer scalar type (passed by value) or a pointer type. If it is a pointer type, the called functions could modify the pointee (allowed by MISRA) but not the parameter variable itself; if FuncKey were some reference-like type, we must confirm no assignment to FuncKey occurs. Knowing the typedef removes ambiguity about whether any usage modifies the parameter variable.

- prototype/declaration of UT_GetStubEntry and UT_Stub_FindRetvalConfig: These callees are invoked with FuncKey and other arguments. Their prototypes confirm whether FuncKey is passed by value (normal) or by pointer/reference and whether any of these functions take pointers into the caller's parameters. This helps determine whether the parameter variables themselves are modified (e.g., via writing through a pointer alias) or are simply used read-only.

- UT_StubContext_t (typedef/struct): Callback prototypes take a pointer to UT_StubContext_t (&LocalContext). Although LocalContext is local, knowing the context type and whether callbacks might store pointers back into structures that alias parameters can be relevant to alias-analysis when proving the parameter variables were not modified. Also some callback prototypes include UT_StubContext_t in their signature which may affect whether ArgList or other parameters are passed or modified.

In short: to decide if any of the function parameters (FunctionName, FuncKey, DefaultRc, ArgList) are being modified by this function, we must know the concrete representation/semantics of va_list and the exact signatures of the callbacks and of the stub-entry APIs (and the typedef of FuncKey). These symbols provide the necessary type and prototype information to determine whether any parameter is written to or effectively modified by calls made within UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs.
